{{multiple image| align = right | direction = vertical | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = | image1 = Covered Jade Cup with Gilt Bronze Fitting, 2nd - 1st century BC, Western Han period, China - Sackler Museum - DSC02596.JPG | width1 = 300 | caption1 = A [[Western Han]] (202 BC - 9 AD) covered [[jade]] cup with gilt bronze fittings, [[Sackler Museum]] | image2 = Boucle Han Chine Guimet 2910.jpg | width2 = 300 | caption2 = An [[Eastern Han]] (25-220 AD) golden [[belt hook]], hammered and chiseled with designs of [[Chinese folk religion|mythical animals and birds]]}}{{chinesetext}} The [[Han dynasty]] (206 BC – 220 AD) of ancient [[China]] experienced contrasting periods of economic prosperity and decline. It is normally divided into three periods: Western Han (206 BC – 9 AD), the [[Xin dynasty]] (9–23 AD), and Eastern Han (25–220 AD). The Xin regime, established by the former regent [[Wang Mang]], formed a brief interregnum between lengthy periods of Han rule. Following the fall of Wang Mang, the Han capital was moved eastward from [[Chang'an]] to [[Luoyang]]. In consequence, historians have named the succeeding eras Western Han and Eastern Han respectively.<ref>{{Harvnb|Hinsch|2002|pp=24–25}}; {{Harvnb|Cullen|2006|p=1}}.</ref>
The Han economy was defined by significant [[population growth]], increasing urbanization, unprecedented growth of industry and trade, and government experimentation with [[nationalization]]. In this era, the levels of minting and circulation of [[Ancient Chinese coinage|coin currency]] grew significantly, forming the foundation of a stable [[monetary system]]. The [[Silk Road]] facilitated the establishment of trade and tributary exchanges with [[Foreign relations of Imperial China|foreign countries]] across [[Eurasia]], many of which were previously unknown to the [[Chinese people|people of ancient China]]. The imperial capitals of both Western Han (Chang'an) and Eastern Han (Luoyang) were among the largest cities in the world at the time, in both population and area. Here, government workshops manufactured furnishings for the [[Chinese Palaces|palaces]] of the [[Emperor of China|emperor]] and produced goods for the common people. The government oversaw the construction of roads and bridges, which facilitated official government business and encouraged commercial growth. Under Han rule, industrialists, wholesalers, and merchants—from minor shopkeepers to wealthy businessmen—could engage in a wide range of enterprises and trade in the domestic, public, and even military spheres.
In the early Han period, rural peasant farmers were largely self-sufficient, but they began to rely heavily upon commercial exchanges with the wealthy landowners of large agricultural estates. Many peasants fell into debt and were forced to become either hired laborers or rent-paying [[Tenant farmer|tenants]] of the land-owning classes. The Han government continually strove to provide economic aid to poor farmers, who had to compete with powerful and influential [[Four occupations|nobles, landowners, and merchants]]. The government tried to limit the power of these wealthy groups through heavy taxation and bureaucratic regulation. [[Emperor Wu of Han|Emperor Wu's]] (r. 141–87 BC) government even nationalized the iron and salt industries; however, these government monopolies were repealed during Eastern Han. Increasing government intervention in the private economy during the late 2nd century BC severely weakened the commercial merchant class. This allowed wealthy landowners to increase their power and to ensure the continuation of an agrarian-dominated economy. The wealthy landlords eventually dominated commercial activities as well, maintaining control over the rural peasants—upon whom the government relied for tax revenues—military manpower, and public works labor. By the 180s AD, economic and political crises had caused the Han government to become heavily decentralized, while the great landowners became increasingly independent and powerful in their communities.
==Monetary system and urbanization== ===Urbanization and population=== {{further|Society and culture of the Han dynasty|Science and technology of the Han dynasty}} [[File:Pottery tower 6a.JPG|thumb|A painted [[Chinese ceramics|ceramic]] [[Chinese architecture|architectural]] model—found in a Han tomb—depicting an urban residential tower with verandas, tiled rooftops, ''[[dougong]]'' support brackets, and a covered bridge extending from the third floor to another tower]]
During the [[Warring States period]] (403–221 BC), the development of private commerce, new trade routes, handicraft industries, and [[Chinese currency|a money economy]] led to the growth of new urban centers. These centers were markedly different from the older cities, which had merely served as power bases for the [[Chinese nobility|nobility]].<ref name="nishijima 1986 574">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=574}}.</ref> The use of a standardized, nationwide currency during the [[Qin dynasty]] (221–206 BC) facilitated long-distance trade between cities.<ref name="hinsch 2002 28">{{Harvnb|Hinsch|2002|p=28}}.</ref> Many Han cities grew large: the Western Han capital, [[Chang'an]], had approximately 250,000 inhabitants, while the Eastern Han capital, [[Luoyang]], had approximately 500,000 inhabitants.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=574–575}}; {{Harvnb|Stearns|Langer|2001|p=51}}.</ref> The population of the Han Empire, recorded in the tax [[census]] of 2 AD, was 57.6 million people in 12,366,470 households.<ref>{{Harvnb|Schinz|1996|p=136}}; {{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=595–596}}.</ref> The majority of commoners who populated the cities lived in extended urban and suburban areas outside the [[Chinese city wall|city walls]] and [[gatehouse]]s.<ref>{{Harvnb|Schinz|1996|p=140}}; {{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=1–4, & 30}}.</ref> The total urban area of Western-Han Chang'an—including the extensions outside the walls—was {{convert|36|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}. The total urban area of Eastern-Han Luoyang—including the extensions outside the walls—was {{convert|24.5|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=1–4, 30}}; {{Harvnb|Hansen|2000|pp=135–136}}.</ref> Both Chang'an and Luoyang had two prominent marketplaces; each market had a two-story government office demarcated by a flag and drum at the top.<ref name="nishijima 1986 575 576">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=575–576}}.</ref> Market officials were charged with maintaining order, collecting commercial taxes, setting standard commodity prices on a monthly basis, and authorizing contracts between merchants and customers.<ref name="nishijima 1986 575 576"/>
===Variations in currency=== {{further|History of the Han dynasty|Government of the Han dynasty}}
During the early Western Han period, founding [[Emperor Gaozu of Han]] (r. 202–195 BC) closed government [[Mint (coin)|mints]] in favor of [[Ancient Chinese coinage|coin currency]] produced by the [[private sector]].<ref name="nishijima 1986 586">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=586}}.</ref> Gaozu's widow [[Empress Lü Zhi]], as [[grand empress dowager]], abolished private minting in 186 BC. She first issued a government-minted bronze coin weighing {{convert|5.7|g|oz|abbr=on}}, but issued another, weighing {{convert|1.5|g|oz|abbr=on}}, in 182 BC.<ref name="nishijima 1986 586"/> The change to the lighter coin caused widespread inflation, so in 175 BC [[Emperor Wen of Han]] (r. 180–157 BC) lifted the ban on private minting; private mints were required to mint coins weighing exactly {{convert|2.6|g|oz|abbr=on}}.<ref name="nishijima 1986 586"/> Private minting was again abolished in 144 BC during the end of [[Emperor Jing of Han]]'s (r. 157–141 BC) reign. Despite this, the {{convert|2.6|g|oz|abbr=on}} bronze coin was issued by both central and local [[Commandery (China)|commandery]] governments until 120 BC, when for one year it was replaced with a coin weighing {{convert|1.9|g|oz|abbr=on}}.<ref name="nishijima 1986 586 587">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=586–587}}.</ref> Other currencies were introduced around this time. [[Token money]] notes made of embroidered white deerskin, with a face value of 400,000 coins, were used to collect government revenues.<ref name="nishijima 1986 586 587"/> Emperor Wu also introduced three tin-silver alloy coins worth 3,000, 500, and 300 bronze coins, respectively; all of these weighed less than {{convert|120|g|oz|abbr=on}}.<ref name="nishijima 1986 586 587"/>
[[File:S-114 W Han wuzhu, Han Wudi, 140-87, 25 5mm.jpg|left|thumb|A ''wushu'' (五銖) coin issued during the reign of [[Emperor Wu of Han|Emperor Wu]] (r. 141–87 BC), {{convert|25.5|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} in diameter]]
In 119 BC, the government issued the bronze ''wushu'' (五銖) coin weighing {{convert|3.2|g|oz|2|abbr=on}}; the coin remained the standard currency in China until the [[Tang dynasty]] (618–907 AD).<ref name="nishijima 1986 587">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=587}}.</ref> During the brief interruptive [[Xin dynasty]] (9–23 AD) of [[Wang Mang]] (45 BC – 23 AD), the government introduced several new denominations in 7, 9, 10, and 14 AD. These new units (including bronze [[knife money]], gold, silver, tortoise, and cowry shell currencies) often had a market price unequal to their weight and debased the value of coin currency.<ref name="ebrey 1986 609 bielenstein 1986 232 233 nishijima 1986 588"/> Once the widespread civil wars following Wang's overthrow abated, the ''wushu'' coin was reintroduced by [[Emperor Guangwu of Han]] (r. 25–57 AD) in 40 AD at the instigation of [[Ma Yuan (Han dynasty)|Ma Yuan]] (14 BC – 49 AD).<ref name="ebrey 1986 609 bielenstein 1986 232 233 nishijima 1986 588">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=609}}; {{Harvnb|Bielenstein|1986|pp=232–233}}; {{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=588}}.</ref> Since commandery-issued coins were often of inferior quality and lighter weight, the central government closed all commandery mints in 113 BC and granted the central government's [[Government of the Han dynasty#Superintendent of Waterways and Parks|Superintendent of Waterways and Parks]] the exclusive right to mint coins.<ref name="nishijima 1986 587 588">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=587–588}}.</ref> Although the issue of central government coinage was transferred to the office of the [[Government of the Han dynasty#Minister of Finance|Minister of Finance]] (one of [[Nine Ministers]] of the central government) by the beginning of Eastern Han, the central government's monopoly over the issue of coinage persisted.<ref name="bielenstein 1980 83">{{Harvnb|Bielenstein|1980|pp=47 & 83}}.</ref>

===Circulation and salaries=== [[File:Bronze wushu coin mould, Han Dynasty.JPG|thumb|A Han dynasty [[Molding (process)|bronze mold]] for making ''wuzhu'' (五銖) coins; the latter featured a square hole in the center so that strings could pass through and thus allow one to carry many coins at once.]]
[[Four occupations|Merchants and peasant farmers]] paid property and poll taxes in coin cash and land taxes with a portion of their crop yield.<ref name="nishijima 1986 600"/> Peasants obtained coinage by working as hired laborers for rich landowners, in businesses like breweries or by selling agricultural goods and homemade wares at urban markets.<ref name="nishijima 1986 600 601">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=600–601}}.</ref> The Han government may have found collecting taxes in coin the easiest method because the transportation of taxed goods would have been unnecessary.<ref name="nishijima 1986 601">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=601}}.</ref>
From 118 BC to 5 AD, the government minted over 28,000,000,000 coins, with an annual average of 220,000,000 coins minted (or 220,000 strings of 1,000 coins).<ref name="nishijima 1986 588">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=588}}.</ref> In comparison, the [[Chinese era name|Tianbao period]] (天寶) (742–755 AD) of the Tang dynasty produced 327,000,000 coins every year while 3,000,000,000 coins in 1045 AD and 5,860,000,000 coins in 1080 AD were made in the [[Economy of the Song dynasty|Song dynasty]] (960–1279 AD).<ref name="nishijima 1986 588"/> Coin cash became the common measure of wealth during Eastern Han, as many wages were paid solely in cash.<ref name="ebrey 1986 612 613">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=612–613}}.</ref> Diwu Lun (第五倫) ([[floruit|fl.]] 40–85 AD), Governor of Shu Province (modern [[Sichuan]]), described his subordinate officials' wealth not in terms of landholdings, but in the form of aggregate properties worth approximately 10,000,000 coin cash.<ref name="ebrey 1986 612">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=612}}.</ref> Commercial transactions involving hundreds of thousands of coins were commonplace.<ref name="ebrey 1986 612"/>
[[Angus Maddison]] estimates that the country's [[gross domestic product]] was equivalent to $450 per head in 1990 [[United States dollar]]s—a sum that was above subsistence level, and which did not significantly change until the beginning of the Song dynasty in the late 10th century.<ref name="maddison 2001 259">{{Harvnb|Maddison|2001|p=259}}.</ref> Sinologist [[Joseph Needham]] has disputed this and claimed that China's GDP per capita exceeded Europe by substantial margins from the 5th century BCE onwards, holding that Han China was much wealthier than the contemporary [[Roman Empire]].<ref>{{harvnb|Maddison|2007|p=42}}</ref> The widespread circulation of coin cash enriched many merchants, who invested their money in land and became wealthy landowners. The government's efforts to circulate cash had empowered the very social class which it actively tried to suppress through heavy taxes, fines, confiscations, and price regulation schemes.<ref name="nishijima 1986 601"/>
==Taxation, property, and social class==
===Landowners and peasants=== {{further|Society and culture of the Han dynasty}} [[File:China.Terracotta statues007.jpg|thumb|right|A female servant and male advisor dressed in [[Han Chinese clothing|silk robes]], [[Chinese ceramics|ceramic figurines]] from the Western Han Era]]
After [[Shang Yang]] (d. 338 BC) of the [[Qin (state)|State of Qin]] abolished the communal and aristocratic [[well-field system]] in an effort to curb the power of nobles, land in China could be bought and sold.<ref name="nishijima 1986 556">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=556}}.</ref> Historical scholars of the Han dynasty like [[Dong Zhongshu]] (179–104 BC) attributed the rise of the wealthy landowning class to this reform.<ref name="nishijima 1986 556"/> The ''[[Han Feizi (book)|Han Feizi]]'' describes these landowners' use of hired labor in agriculture, a practice dating back to the 3rd century BC, possibly earlier.<ref name="nishijima 1986 556"/> Some landowners owned small numbers of slaves, but many relied on peasant tenant farmers who paid rent with a portion of their agricultural produce.<ref name="hinsch 2002 28"/><ref name="nishijima 1986 556 557">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=556–557}}.</ref> More numerous than tenants, small landowner-cultivators lived and worked independently, but often fell into debt and sold their land to the wealthy.<ref name="hinsch 2002 28"/> The court official [[Chao Cuo]] (d. 154 BC) argued that if the average independent landowning family of five could cultivate no more than {{convert|4.57|ha|acre|1}} of land and produce no more than {{convert|2000|l|USgal|lk=on}} of grain annually, then natural disasters and high taxation rates would force many into debt, to sell their land, homes, and even children, and to become dependent upon work as tenant farmers for the wealthy.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=556–557 & 577–578}}; {{Harvnb|Ebrey|1999|pp=73–74}}; {{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=58–59}}.</ref>
Officials at the court of [[Emperor Ai of Han]] (r. 7–1 BC) attempted to implement reforms limiting the amount of land nobles and wealthy landowners could own legally, but were unsuccessful.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=557–558}}; see also {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=183}}.</ref> When [[Wang Mang]] took control of the government in 9 AD, he abolished the purchase and sale of land in a system called King's Fields (王田). This was a variation of the well-field system, where the government owned the land and assured every peasant an equal share to cultivate.<ref name="nishijima 1986 557 558 hansen 2000 134 bielenstein 1986 232 lewis 2007 23 hucker 1975 183">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=557–558}}; {{Harvnb|Hansen|2000|p=134}}; {{Harvnb|Bielenstein|1986|p=232}}; {{Harvnb|Lewis|2007|p=23}}; {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=183}}.</ref> Within three years, complaints from wealthy landowners and nobles forced Wang Mang to repeal the reform.<ref name="nishijima 1986 557 558 hansen 2000 134 bielenstein 1986 232 lewis 2007 23 hucker 1975 183"/> After [[Emperor Gengshi of Han|Gengshi]] (r. 23–25 AD) and [[Emperor Guangwu of Han|Guangwu]] (r. 25–57 AD) restored the Han dynasty, they relied on the service of great landholding families to secure their position in society. Many of their government officials also became wealthy landowners.<ref name="nishijima 1986 558 559">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=558–559}}; see also {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=183}}.</ref>
[[File:Pottery well.JPG|thumb|left|A Han pottery model of a roofed water well with a bucket]]
By the late Eastern Han period, the peasantry had become largely landless and served wealthy landowners. This cost the government significant tax revenue.<ref name="nishijima 1986 558 559b">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=558–559}}.</ref> Although the central government under [[Emperor He of Han]] (r. 88–105 AD) reduced taxes in times of natural disaster and distress without much effect upon the treasury, successive rulers became less able to cope with major crises. The government soon relied upon local administrations to conduct relief efforts.<ref name="ebrey 1986 621">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=621}}.</ref> After the central government failed to provide local governments with provisions during both a locust swarm and the flooding of the [[Yellow River]] in 153 AD, many landless peasants became [[Retainer agreement|retainer]]s of large landowners in exchange for aid.<ref name="ebrey 1986 621 622">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=621–622}}.</ref> Patricia Ebrey writes that the Eastern Han was the "transitional period" between the Western Han—when small independent farmers were the vast majority—and the [[Three Kingdoms]] (220–265 AD) and later [[Sixteen Kingdoms]] (304–439 AD), when large family estates used [[Serfdom|unfree labor]].<ref name="ebrey 1974 173 174">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1974|pp=173–174}}.</ref>
The [[Yellow Turban Rebellion]] of 184 AD, the [[Ten Attendants|slaughter of the eunuchs]] in 189 AD, and the [[campaign against Dong Zhuo]] in 190 AD destabilized the central government, and [[History of the Han dynasty|Luoyang was burnt to the ground]].<ref>{{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|p=515}}; {{Harvnb|Ebrey|1999|p=84}}; {{Harvnb|Beck|1986|pp=344–345 & 347–349}}.</ref> At this point, "... private and local power came to replace public authority."<ref name="ebrey 1974 173 174"/>
[[File:EasternHan-GreenGlazedPotteryDuck-ShanghaiMuseum-May27-08.jpg|thumb|right|Low-fired green-glazed [[Chinese ceramics|pottery figure]] of a duck from the time of the Eastern Han Era]] [[File:Han tomb figurines, Luoyang.jpg|thumb|Eastern-Han ceramic figurines of an ox-drawn cart, a horse, and human figures, found in a tomb at [[Luoyang]]]] The Han [[Chancellor]] and [[Cao Wei|King of Wei]] [[Cao Cao]] (155–220 AD) made the final significant attempt to limit the power of wealthy landowners. Cao Cao established government-managed [[Tuntian|agricultural colonies]] for landless commoners; in exchange for land and cheap equipment, the farmers paid a portion of their crop yield.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|p=61}}; {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=183}}.</ref> In the 120s BC, Emperor Wu had attempted to establish agricultural colonies in the northwestern frontier of the newly conquered [[Hexi Corridor]] (in modern [[Gansu]]). 600,000 new settlers farmed on these state lands using seeds, draft animals and equipment loaned by the government.<ref name="deng 1999 76">{{Harvnb|Deng|1999|p=76}}.</ref> An imperial edict in 85 AD ordered the local governments of commanderies and [[Kings of the Han dynasty|subordinate kingdoms]] to resettle landless peasants onto state-owned lands, where they would be paid wages, provided with crop seeds, loaned farming tools and exempted from rent payments for five years and poll taxes for three years.<ref name="ebrey 1986 619">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=619}}.</ref> The edict also allowed peasants to return to their native [[Counties of the People's Republic of China#History|counties]] at any time.<ref name="ebrey 1986 619"/> Subsequent governments of the Three Kingdoms established agricultural colonies on these models.<ref name="deng 1999 77">{{Harvnb|Deng|1999|p=77}}.</ref>
===Tax reforms===
Because small landowning families represented the mainstay of the Han tax base, the Han government attempted to aid and protect small landowners and to limit the power of wealthy landlords and merchants.<ref name="ebrey 1999 75">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1999|p=75}}.</ref> The government reduced taxes in times of poor harvest and provided relief after disasters.<ref name="ebrey 1999 75 hucker 1975 182 183">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1999|p=75}}; {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|pp=182–183}}.</ref> [[Tax break|Tax remission]]s and crop seed loans encouraged displaced peasants to return to their land.<ref name="ebrey 1999 75 hucker 1975 182 183"/> An edict in 94 AD excused displaced peasants from paying land and labor service taxes for a year upon returning to their own farms.<ref name="ebrey 1986 620 621">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=620–621}}.</ref> The [[Land value tax|land tax]] on agricultural production was reduced in 168 BC from a rate of one-fifteenth of crop yield to one-thirtieth, and abolished in 167 BC. However, the tax was reinstated in 156 BC at a rate of one-thirtieth.<ref>{{Harvnb|Loewe|1986|pp=149–150}}; {{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=596–598}}; see also {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=181}}.</ref> At the beginning of the Eastern Han, the land tax rate was one-tenth of the crop yield, but following the stabilization following Wang Mang's death, the rate was reduced to the original one-thirtieth in 30 AD.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=596–598}}; {{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=618–619}}.</ref>
Towards the end of the Han dynasty, the land tax rate was reduced to one-hundredth, with lost revenue recouped by increasing the [[Tax per head|poll]] and property tax rates.<ref name="nishijima 1986 596 598">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=596–598}}.</ref> The poll tax for most adults was 120 coins annually, 240 coins for merchants, and 20 coins for minors aged between three and fourteen years. The lower taxable threshold age for minors increased to seven years during the reign of [[Emperor Yuan of Han]] (r. 48–33 BC) and onwards.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=598}}; see also {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=181}}.</ref> Historian [[Charles Hucker]] writes that underreporting of the population by local authorities was deliberate and widespread, since this reduced their tax and labor service obligations rendered to the central government.<ref>{{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=171}}.</ref>
[[File:China.Terracotta statues006.jpg|thumb|left|A Western-Han [[Chinese ceramics|ceramic figurine]] of a mounted [[cavalry]]man, 2nd century BC]]
Though requiring additional revenue to fund the [[Han–Xiongnu War]], the government during [[Emperor Wu of Han]]'s reign (141–87 BC) sought to avoid heavy taxation of small landowners. To increase revenue, the government imposed heavier taxes on merchants, confiscated land from nobles, sold offices and titles, and established government [[monopoly|monopolies]] over the minting of coins, [[History of ferrous metallurgy|iron manufacture]] and salt mining.<ref name="ebrey 1999 75"/> New taxes were imposed on the ownership of boats, carts, carriages, wheelbarrows, shops and other properties. The overall property tax for merchants was raised in 119 BC from 120 coins for every 10,000 coins-worth of property owned to 120 coins for every 2,000 coins-worth of property owned.<ref>{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1999|p=75}}; {{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=599}}.</ref> Tax rates for almost all commodities are unknown, except for that of [[Chinese alcoholic beverages|liquor]]. After the government monopoly on liquor was abolished in 81 BC, a property tax of 2 coins for every {{convert|0.2|l|USgal|2}} was levied on liquor merchants.<ref name="nishijima 1986 600">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=600}}.</ref>
The sale of certain offices and titles was reintroduced in Eastern Han by [[Empress Deng Sui|Empress Dowager Deng Sui]]—who reigned as [[regent]] from 105–121 AD—to raise government revenues in times of severe natural disasters and the widespread rebellion of the [[Qiang people]] in [[western China]].<ref name="de crespigny 2007 126 127">{{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|pp=126–127}}.</ref> The sale of offices became extremely corrupt under the [[Eunuch (court official)|eunuch]]-dominated government of [[Emperor Ling of Han]] (r. 168–189 AD), when many top official posts were sold at the highest bidder instead of being filled by vetted candidates who had taken [[Imperial examinations]] or attended the [[Taixue|Imperial University]].<ref>{{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|pp=126–127}}; {{Harvnb|Kramers|1986|pp=754–756}}; {{Harvnb|Ebrey|1999|pp=77–78}}.</ref>
===Conscription=== {{further|Government of the Han dynasty|Corvée}} [[File:Western Han soldiers 2.jpg|thumb|Painted ceramic cavalrymen and infantrymen, Western Han dynasty]] Two forms of mass [[conscription]] existed during the Han period. These were civilian conscription (''gengzu'' 更卒) and military conscription (''zhengzu'' 正卒). In addition to paying their monetary and crop taxes, all peasants of the Western Han period aged between fifteen and fifty-six were required to undertake mandatory conscription duties for one month of each year. These duties were usually fulfilled by work on construction projects.<ref name="nishijima 1986 599">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=599}}.</ref>
At the age of twenty-three years male peasants were drafted to serve in the military, where they were assigned to [[infantry]], [[Horses in East Asian warfare|cavalry]], or [[Naval history of China|navy]] service.<ref name="nishijima 1986 599"/> After one year of training, they went on to perform a year of actual military service in frontier garrisons or as guards in the capital city.<ref name="nishijima 1986 599"/> They remained liable to perform this year of service until the age of fifty-six.<ref name="nishijima 1986 599"/> This was also the age when they were dismissed from their local [[militia]]s, which they could join once they had finished their year of conscripted service.<ref>{{Harvnb|Bielenstein|1980|p=114}}.</ref> These non-professional conscripted soldiers comprised the Southern Army (''Nanjun'' 南軍), while the Northern Army (''Beijun'' 北軍) was a [[standing army]] composed of paid career soldiers.<ref>{{Harvnb|Bielenstein|1980|pp=114–115}}.</ref>
During the Eastern Han, peasants could avoid the month of annual conscripted labor by paying a tax in commutation (''gengfu'' 更賦). This development went hand in hand with the increasing use of hired labor by the government.<ref>{{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|pp=564–565}}; {{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=613}}.</ref> In a similar manner, because the Eastern-Han government favored the military recruitment of volunteers, the mandatory military draft for peasants aged twenty-three could be avoided by paying a tax in substitution.<ref name="de crespigny 2007 564 565">{{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|pp=564–565}}.</ref>
===Merchants=== [[File:Gold animals.JPG|thumb|[[Gilding|Gilded]] bronze animal figurines from the Han dynasty, including a horse, elephant, cow, and unicorn]]
There were two categories of Han merchants: those who sold goods at shops in urban markets, and the larger-scale itinerant traders who traveled between cities and to foreign countries.<ref name="nishijima 1986 576">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=576}}.</ref> The small-scale urban shopkeepers were enrolled on an official register and had to pay heavy commercial taxes.<ref name="nishijima 1986 576"/> Although these registered merchants were taxed, an edict of 94 AD ordered that landless peasants who had to resort to peddling were to be exempted from taxation.<ref name="ebrey 1986 620 621"/>
Itinerant merchants were often wealthy and did not have to register.<ref name="nishijima 1986 576"/> These itinerant merchants often participated in large-scale trade with powerful families and officials.<ref name="nishijima 1986 576"/> Nishijima writes that most of the biographies of "wealthy men" in the ''[[Records of the Grand Historian]]'' and ''[[Book of Han]]'' were those of itinerant merchants.<ref name="nishijima 1986 576"/>
In contrast, registered marketplace merchants had a very low social status and were often subject to additional restrictions.<ref name="nishijima 1986 577 hucker 1975 187">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=577}}; see also {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=187}}.</ref> Emperor Gaozu passed laws levying higher taxes, forbidding merchants from wearing silk, and barring their descendants from holding [[Civil service|public office]]. These laws were difficult to enforce.<ref name="nishijima 1986 577 hucker 1975 187"/> Emperor Wu targeted both the registered and unregistered merchants with higher taxes. While registered merchants were not allowed to own land, if they broke this law their land and slaves would be confiscated.<ref name="nishijima 1986 577 hucker 1975 187"/> However, wealthy unregistered merchants owned large tracts of land.<ref>Ch'ü (1972), 113–114; see also {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=187}}.</ref> Emperor Wu significantly reduced the economic influence of great merchants by openly competing with them in the marketplace, where he set up government-managed shops that sold commodities collected from the merchants as property taxes.<ref name="ebrey 1999 75"/>
==Crafts, industries, and government employment==
===Private manufacture and government monopolies=== {{further|Science and technology of the Han dynasty#Metallurgy}} [[File:Pottery gristmill.JPG|thumb|right|A miniature ceramic model of a [[gristmill]] from a Han tomb]]
====Iron and salt==== At the beginning of the Han dynasty, [[Salt in Chinese history#Ancient China and the early empire|China's salt and iron enterprises]] were privately owned by a number of wealthy merchants and [[Kings of the Han dynasty|subordinate regional kings]]. The profits of these industries rivaled the funds of the imperial court.<ref name="nishijima 1986 583 584">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=583–584}}.</ref> A successful iron or salt industrialist might have employed over a thousand peasants, causing a severe loss of agricultural tax revenue to the central government.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=584}}; {{Harvnb|Needham|1965|p=22}}.</ref> To restrict the power of the industrialists, Emperor Wu had [[Nationalization|nationalized]] the salt and iron industries by 117 BC.<ref>{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1999|p=75}}; {{Harvnb|Hinsch|2002|pp=21–22}}; {{Harvnb|Wagner|2001|pp=1–2}}.</ref>
The government also instituted a liquor monopoly in 98 BC. However, this was repealed in 81 BC in an effort to reduce government intervention in the private economy.<ref name="wagner 2001 13 14">{{Harvnb|Wagner|2001|pp=13–14}}.</ref>
The Reformist Party supported privatization, opposing the Modernist Party, which had dominated politics during the reign of Emperor Wu and the subsequent [[regent|regency]] of [[Huo Guang]] (d. 68 BC).<ref name="loewe 1986 187 206">{{Harvnb|Loewe|1986|pp=187–206}}.</ref> The Modernists argued that state monopolies provided abundant raw materials, good working conditions, and high quality iron; the Reformists countered that state-owned ironworks produced large and impractical implements designed to meet [[quota share|quota]]s rather than to be of practical use, were of inferior quality, and were too expensive for commoners to purchase.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wagner|2001|pp=56–57}}.</ref> In 44 BC, the Reformists had both the salt and iron monopolies abolished, but the monopolies were reinstated in 41 BC after their abrupt closure resulted in significant losses of revenue for the government and disruption of the private economy.<ref name="wagner 2001 15">{{Harvnb|Wagner|2001|p=15}}.</ref>
Wang Mang preserved these central government monopolies. When Eastern Han began, they were once again repealed, the industries given to local commandery governments and private entrepreneurs.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wagner|2001|pp=15–17}}; {{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=584}}.</ref> [[Emperor Zhang of Han]] (r. 75–88 AD) briefly reintroduced the central government monopolies on salt and iron from 85 to 88 AD, but abolished them in the last year of his reign. After Emperor Zhang, the Han never returned the salt and iron industries to government ownership.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wagner|2001|p=17}}; see also {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=190}}.</ref>
[[File:Earthenware architecture models, Eastern Han Dynasty, 6.JPG|thumb|left|An Eastern-Han glazed ceramic model of a furnace]]
====Grain====
The grain trade was a profitable private enterprise during the early Western Han, yet Emperor Wu's government intervened in the grain trade when it established the ''equable marketing system'' (also known as the ''[[ever-normal granary]] system'') in 110 BC.<ref>{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1999|p=75}}; {{Harvnb|Wagner|2001|p=13}}; {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|pp=188–189}}.</ref> The government purchased grain when it was plentiful and inexpensive, shipping it to granaries for storage or to areas where grain was scarce.<ref name="ebrey 1999 75 hucker 1975 189">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1999|p=75}}; {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=189}}.</ref> The system was intended to eliminate grain speculation, to create a standard price and to increase government revenue.<ref name="ebrey 1999 75 hucker 1975 189"/> The system was designed by civil servant [[Sang Hongyang]] (d. 80 BC)—who was previously a merchant. Sang Hongyang was criticized by merchants for placing government officials in market stalls.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wagner|2001|p=13}}; {{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=189}}.</ref> This supply system was discontinued in Eastern Han, although it was briefly revived by [[Emperor Ming of Han]] (r. 57–75). Emperor Ming also abolished the system in 68 AD, when he believed that the government's storage of grain increased prices and made wealthy landowners richer.<ref name="de crespigny 2007 605">{{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|p=605}}.</ref>
Ebrey argues that although most of Emperor Wu's fiscal policies were repealed during Eastern Han, their damage to the merchant class and the subsequent [[laissez-faire]] policies of Eastern Han allowed the wealthiest landowners to dominate society, ensuring that China's economy would remain firmly agrarian-based for centuries.<ref name="ebrey 1999 75"/> The Eastern Han central government lost an important source of revenue by relinquishing its salt and iron industries and purchasing its armies' swords and shields from private manufacturers. However, this loss of revenue was often compensated by higher taxes levied on the merchants.<ref name="ebrey 1986 609">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=609}}.</ref>
===Government workshops=== {{further|Government of the Han dynasty}} [[File:Eastern Han bronze mirror.jpg|thumb|The reverse, decorated side of an Eastern-Han [[TLV mirror|bronze mirror]] with feline heads in a scalloped field; the mirror is inscribed with the date of manufacture (174 AD)]]
Han government workshops produced common, luxury, and even artistic funerary items, such as the ceramic figurines and tomb tiles which adorned the walls of underground tombs.<ref>{{Harvnb|Bower|2005|p=242}}; {{Harvnb|Ruitenbeek|2005|p=253}}; {{Harvnb|Steinhardt|2005|p=278}}.</ref> Imperial workshops were operated by the Minister Steward, whose ministry controlled the treasury and the emperor's private finances.<ref name="nishijima 1986 581">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=581}}.</ref>
The ''Office of Arts and Crafts'', subordinate to the Minister Steward, produced weapons, [[TLV mirror|bronze mirrors]], vessel wares, and other goods.<ref name="nishijima 1986 581"/> ''The Office of Manufactures'', also subordinate to the Minister Steward, made the cheaper weapons, utensils, and [[Chinese armour|armor]].<ref name="nishijima 1986 581"/> Textiles and [[Han Chinese clothing|clothing]] worn by the emperor and royal family were made in the ''Weaving House of the West'' and ''Weaving House of the East''; the latter was abolished in 28 BC, and the ''Weaving House of the West'' was renamed the ''Weaving House''.<ref name="nishijima 1986 581"/>
Workshops located in the commanderies made silks and embroidered fabrics, silver and gold luxury items, and weapons. One workshop, in modern [[Anhui]] province, had a shipyard where battle ships were built.<ref name="nishijima 1986 582">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=582}}.</ref> Although the government used the labor of state-owned slaves, corvée laborers, and convicts in its workshops, they also hired [[Master craftsman|skilled craftsmen]] who were well-paid.<ref name="nishijima 1986 583">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=583}}.</ref>
Han [[lacquerware]]s were privately made as well as being manufactured in government workshops.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=84–85}}; {{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=582}}.</ref> Hundreds of laborers could be employed to work on a single luxury item, such as a [[lacquer]]ed cup or screen.<ref name="wang 1982 83">{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|p=83}}.</ref> Some lacquerwares were inscribed simply with the [[Chinese surname|clan name]] of the family who owned them. Others were inscribed with the titles of the owner, the specific type of the vessels, their capacities, the precise day, month, and year of manufacture (according to [[Chinese era name]]s and their [[Chinese calendar|lunisolar calendar]]), the names of the floor managers who oversaw the items' production and the names of the workers who made them.<ref name="wang 1982 84 85">{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=84–85}}.</ref> Even some iron implements made during the age of the monopoly bore inscriptions of the date they were made and the name of the workshop.<ref name="wang 1982 125">{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|p=125}}.</ref> Bronze calipers from the [[Xin dynasty]], used for minute measurements, had an inscription stating that it was "made on a ''gui-you'' day at new moon of the first month of the first year of the Shijian guo period." The calipers date from 9 AD.<ref name="Ronan">{{cite book|author1=Colin A. Ronanm|author2=Joseph Needha|title=The Shorter Science and Civilisation in China:|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PehoSnJfstUC&pg=PA312|accessdate=15 February 2013|date=24 June 1994|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-32995-8|page=312|quote=adjustable outside caliper gauge... self-dated at AD 9}}</ref> Han lacquerwares bearing the [[Seal (East Asia)|imperial mark]] of the emperor have been found far beyond the Han capital regions by modern archaeologists, in places such as [[Qingzhen]] (in [[Guizhou]]), [[Pyongyang]] (in [[North Korea]]), and [[Noin-Ula kurgans|Noin Ula]] (in [[Mongolia]]).<ref name="wang 1982 86 87">{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=86–87}}.</ref>
===Public construction projects=== {{further|Government of the Han dynasty}} The Court Architect was charged by central government with overseeing all [[Chinese architecture|imperial construction and public works projects]], including the building of palaces and tombs.<ref name="nishijima 1986 581 582">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=581–582}}.</ref> [[File:Pottery palace.JPG|thumb|left|A Han dynasty pottery tomb model of [[Siheyuan|a palatial residence]] with [[watchtower]]s, [[Chinese architecture|gatehouses, halls, outer walls]], [[Courtyard house|courtyards]], verandas, tiled rooftops, and windows]]
During the Western Han period, conscripted peasants were organized into work teams consisting of over a hundred thousand laborers. About 150,000 conscripted workers, serving in consecutive periods of thirty days each over a total of five years, worked on the massive defensive walls of Chang'an, which were completed in 190 BC.<ref name="loewe 1986 130 131">{{Harvnb|Loewe|1986|pp=130–131}}.</ref> Conscript laborers were commissioned to build and maintain shrines dedicated to various [[Chinese folk religion|deities]] and the [[Ancestor worship|spirits of the emperor's ancestors]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Loewe|1986|pp=130–131, 207–209}}.</ref> Conscripts also maintained canal systems used for agricultural transport and irrigation.<ref name="wang 1982 55 56">{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=55–56}}.</ref> Some of the larger Han canal renovation projects included repairs to the [[Dujiangyan Irrigation System]] and [[Zhengguo Canal]], built by the previous State of Qin and [[Qin dynasty]] (221–206 BC), respectively.<ref name="wang 1982 55 56"/>
Nineteen stone inscriptions survive commemorating the building of new roads and bridges by the Eastern Han government.<ref name="ebrey 1986 613 614"/> Archaeological excavations at Chang'an show that wooden bridges were built over the defensive moat and led to the gatehouses.<ref name="wang 1982 2">{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|p=2}}.</ref> Roadways also needed periodic repairs; in 63 AD the route leading from the [[Qilian Mountains]], through [[Hanzhong]] (modern southern [[Shanxi]]), and towards the capital Luoyang underwent major repairs.<ref name="ebrey 1986 613 614">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=613–614}}.</ref> For this project, 623 [[trestle]] bridges, five large bridges, 107 km (66 mi) of new roadways, and 64 buildings—including [[Inn|rest houses]], [[mail|post stations]], and [[courier|relay stations]]—were built.<ref name="ebrey 1986 613 614"/> Those commissioned with military authority also built bridges. For example, during his [[Han–Xiongnu War|campaign against the Xiongnu]] in the [[Ordos Desert]] in 127 BC, the general [[Wei Qing]] (d. 106 BC) had a new bridge built over the Wujia River (a former tributary of the [[Yellow River]]) in today's [[Inner Mongolia]]. He used this bridge to move troops and supplies for an attack on the Xiongnu, northwest of modern Wuyuan County (五原县).<ref name="di cosmo 2002 238">{{Harvnb|Di Cosmo|2002|p=238}}.</ref> Ebrey writes:<ref name="ebrey 1986 614"/>
<blockquote>There were, of course, numerous reasons for maintaining roads. A unified political system could be maintained only as long as the government had the means of quickly dispatching officials, troops, or messengers as needed. Such a system of transportation, once established, facilitated commerce. At the local level, road and bridge projects seem to have been initiated as much for the sake of traveling merchants as for officials.<ref name="ebrey 1986 614">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=614}}.</ref></blockquote>
==Domestic trade==
===Traded goods and commodities=== [[File:Lacquer flanged cups and dishes.jpg|thumb|right|A set of red-and-black [[lacquerware]] flanged cups and dishes from tomb no. 1 at [[Mawangdui|Mawangdui Han tombs site]], 2nd century BC, Western Han dynasty]]
Han-era historians like [[Sima Qian]] (145–86 BC) and [[Ban Gu]] (32–92 AD), as well as the later historian [[Fan Ye (historian)|Fan Ye]] (398–445 AD), recorded details of the business transactions and products traded by Han merchants. Evidence of these products has also emerged from archaeological investigations.
The main agricultural staple foods during the Han dynasty were foxtail millet, proso millet, rice (including glutinous rice), wheat, beans, and barley.<ref name="wang 1982 52">{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|p=52}}.</ref> Other food items included sorghum, taro, mallow, mustard plant, jujube, pear, plum (including ''[[Prunus salicina]]'' and ''[[Prunus mume]]''), peach, apricot, and [[myrica]].<ref name="wang 1982 53">{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|p=53}}.</ref> Chicken, duck, goose, beef, pork, rabbit, [[sika deer]], turtle dove, owl, [[Chinese bamboo partridge]], magpie, common pheasant, crane, and various types of fish were commonly consumed meats.<ref name="wang 1982 57 203">{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=57 & 203}}.</ref>
The production of silk through [[sericulture]] was profitable for both small-time farmers and large-scale producers. Silk clothing was too expensive for the poor, who wore clothes most commonly made of hemp.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=53 & 58}}.</ref> The rural women usually wove all the family's clothes.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=585}}; {{Harvnb|Hinsch|2002|pp=59–60 & 65}}.</ref>
Common bronze items included domestic wares like oil lamps, incense burners, tables, irons, stoves, and dripping jars. Iron goods were often used for construction and farmwork, such as plowshares, pickaxes, spades, shovels, hoes, sickles, axes, [[adze]], hammers, chisels, knives, saws, [[scratch awl]]s, and nails.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|pp=103 & 122}}.</ref> Iron was also used to make [[Chinese swords|swords]], [[ji (halberd)|halberds]], arrowheads and [[scale armor]] for the military.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wang|1982|p=123}}.</ref>
[[File:Pottery dogs, Han Dynasty.JPG|thumb|left|Although dog meat was eaten during the Han, [[Dogs in ancient China|dogs]] were also domesticated as pets. Most dogs were kept as pets, while specific types were bred for consumption.;<ref name="wang 1982 57 203"/> these two Han tomb pottery dogs are wearing decorative [[dog collar]]s.]]
Other common goods included: consumables (liquor, pickles and sauces, sheep and pigs, grain, yeast for fermentation, bean relish, dried fish and abalone, dates, chestnuts, fruits and vegetables), raw materials (cattle hide, boat timber, bamboo poles, dyes, horns, cinnabar, raw lacquer, jade, amber), clothing and clothing materials (silk fabrics, fine and coarse cloth, sable and foxskin garments, felt and mats, deerskin slippers), eating utensils (bronze utensils and chopsticks, silver, wood and iron vessels, ceramic wares), art objects (lacquerware, ceramics), elegant coffins (made of catalpa, [[Robinia pseudoacacia|locust]], juniper, and lacquered wood), vehicles such as light two-wheeled carts and heavy oxcarts, and horses.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=578–579}}; {{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=609–611}}.</ref>
In addition to general commodities, Han historians list the goods of specific regions. Common trade items from the region of modern [[Shanxi]] included bamboo, timber, grain, and gemstones; [[Shandong]] had fish, salt, liquor, and silk; [[Jiangnan]] had [[camphor]], catalpa, ginger, cinnamon, gold, tin, lead, cinnabar, rhinoceros horn, tortoise shell, pearls, ivory, and leather.<ref name="nishijima 1986 578 579">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=578–579}}.</ref> Ebrey lists items found in a 2nd-century AD tomb in [[Wuwei, Gansu]] (along the [[Hexi Corridor]] fortified by the [[Great Wall of China]]), evidence that luxury items could be obtained even in remote frontiers.<ref name="ebrey 1986 611 612">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=611–612}}.</ref>
<blockquote>... fourteen pieces of pottery; wooden objects such as a horse, pig, ox, chicken, chicken coop, and a single-horned animal; seventy copper cash; a crossbow mechanism made of bronze; a writing brush; a lacquer-encased inkstone; a lacquer tray and bowl; a wooden comb; a jade ornament; a pair of hemp shoes; a straw bag; the remains of an inscribed banner; a bamboo hairpin; two straw satchels; and a stone lamp.<ref name="ebrey 1986 611 612"/></blockquote>
===Estate management and trade=== {{further|Society and culture of the Han dynasty}} [[File:CMOC Treasures of Ancient China exhibit - pictorial brick depicting a courtyard scene.jpg|thumb|This incised Eastern-Han brick, from the chamber wall of a rich and powerful family's tomb in [[Chengdu]], depicts [[Siheyuan|the home of a wealthy, influential Han official]]; it features a walled courtyard, house, bedrooms, halls, kitchen, well, and a watchtower. The host and his guest sit and drink in the inner courtyard, while two [[Fighting cocks|roosters]] fight and two cranes dance.]] [[File:Kunming Oct 2007 031.jpg|thumb|Bronze cowrie container, [[Western Han Dynasty]] (202 BC - 9 AD), [[Yunnan Provincial Museum]], Kunming; [[Shell money|cowrie shells]] were used as an early form of money in [[History of Yunnan|this region of China]] and were kept in elaborately decorated bronze containers such as this one, surmounted by a freestanding [[Gilding|gilded]] [[Horses in East Asian warfare|horseman]] who is encircled by four oxen, that are approached in turn by two tigers climbing up on opposite sides of the container.]] In the early Eastern Han, Emperor Ming passed laws which prohibited those involved in agriculture from simultaneously engaging in mercantile trade.<ref name="ebrey 1986 615">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=615}}.</ref> These laws were largely ineffective, since wealthy landowners and landlords made significant profits from the trading of goods produced on their estates.<ref name="ebrey 1986 615"/> Cui Shi (催寔) (d. 170 AD), a local commandery administrator who later served as an official in the central government's secretariat, started a winery business in his home to pay for his father's funeral. His fellow [[Gentry (China)|gentry]] criticized him, claiming the practice was immoral, but not illegal.<ref name="ebrey 1986 615"/>
Cui Shi's book ''Simin yueling'' (四民月令) is the only significant surviving work on [[Agriculture in China|agriculture]] from the Eastern Han period,<ref name="nishijima 1986 566 567">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=566–567}}.</ref> though about 3,000 [[Chinese character|written characters]] of the ''Fan Shengzhi shu'' (氾勝之書), dated to the reign of [[Emperor Cheng of Han]] (33–7 BC), still survive.<ref name="nishijima 1986 564">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=564}}.</ref> Cui Shi's book provides descriptions of rituals for [[ancestor worship]], festival and religious [[Traditional Chinese holidays|holiday celebrations]], conduct for [[Chinese kinship|family and kinship relations]], farmwork, and the schooling season for boys. Cui Shi's book also provides detailed instructions on which months were the most profitable times to buy and sell certain types of farm-produced goods.<ref>{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=615}}; {{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=567–568}}.</ref>
The following table is modelled on Ebrey's "Estate and Family Management in the Later Han as Seen in the Monthly Instructions for the Four Classes of People" (1974).<ref name="ebrey 1974 198">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1974|p=198}}.</ref> Ebrey writes: "... the same item was often bought and sold at different times of the year. The rationale for this is very clearly financial: items were bought when the price was low and sold when it was high."<ref name="ebrey 1974 198"/> The specific amounts for each commodity traded are not listed, yet the timing of sale and purchase during the year is the most valuable information for historians.<ref name="ebrey 1974 197 199">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1974|pp=197–199}}.</ref> Missing from Cui Shi's list are important items which his family certainly bought and sold at specific times of the year, such as salt, iron farm tools and kitchen utensils, paper and ink (the [[papermaking]] process was invented by [[Cai Lun]] in 105 AD),<ref>{{Harvnb|Tom|1989|p=99}}; {{Harvnb|Cotterell|2004|p=11}}.</ref> as well as luxury items of silk and exotic foods.<ref name="ebrey 1974 199">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1974|p=199}}.</ref>

[[File:China.Terracotta statues028.jpg|thumb|left|Ceramic pigs and oxen from a tomb of the Western Han Era]]
There was mass unemployment among landless peasants during the Eastern Han period. However, archaeological and literary evidence shows that those managing wealthy agricultural estates enjoyed great prosperity and lived comfortably.<ref name="ebrey 1986 622 626">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=622–626}}.</ref> In addition to Cui's work, the [[List of Chinese inventions|inventor]], [[Chinese mathematics|mathematician]], and [[Chinese astronomy|court astronomer]] [[Zhang Heng]] (78–139 AD) wrote a [[Fu (poetry)|rhapsody]] describing the rich countryside of [[Nanyang, Henan|Nanyang]] and its [[Paddy field|irrigated rice paddies]]. He mentions grain fields, ponds filled with fish, and [[Chinese garden|estate gardens]] and orchards filled with bamboo shoots, autumn leeks, winter rape-turnips, [[perilla]], [[Tetradium|evodia]], and purple ginger.<ref>{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=624}}; {{Harvnb|Knechtges|1997|p=232}}.</ref>
Bricks lining the walls of the tombs of wealthy Han were adorned with carved or molded reliefs and painted murals; these often showed scenes of the tomb occupant's estate, halls, wells, carriage sheds, pens for cattle, sheep, chickens, and pigs, stables for horses, and employed workers picking [[Morus (plant)|mulberry leaves]], plowing crop fields, and hoeing vegetable patches.<ref name="ebrey 1986 622 623">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=622–623}}.</ref>
Small and medium-sized estates were managed by single families. The father acted as the head manager, the sons as field workers. Wives and daughters worked with female servants to weave cloth and produce silk.<ref name="ebrey 1986 626">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|p=626}}.</ref> Very wealthy landowners who had a large peasant following often used a [[sharecropping]] system to similar to the government's system for state-owned lands. Under this system, peasants would receive land, tools, oxen, and a house in exchange for a third or a half of their crop yield.<ref name="ebrey 1986 625 626">{{Harvnb|Ebrey|1986|pp=625–626}}.</ref>
==Foreign trade and tributary exchange== {{Main article|Foreign relations of Imperial China|Silk Road|Serica|Daqin|Sino-Roman relations}} [[File:Woven silk, Western Han Dynasty.jpg|thumb|right|Woven silk textile from Tomb No. 1 at [[Mawangdui|Mawangdui Han tombs site]], [[Changsha]], [[Hunan]] province, China, dated to the Western Han Era, 2nd century BC]] [[Image:Xihan rhino, gold & silver inlays.JPG|thumb|A bronze rhinoceros from the Western Han Era]]
Prior to the Han dynasty, markets close to China's northern border engaged in trade with the nomadic tribes of the eastern [[Eurasian Steppe]].<ref name="liu 1988 14">{{Harvnb|Liu|1988|p=14}}.</ref> The [[heqin]] agreement between the Han and nomadic [[Xiongnu]] stipulated the transfer of tributary goods from China. The exact amount of annual tribute sent to the Xiongnu in the 2nd century BC is unknown. In 89 BC, when Hulugu Chanyu (狐鹿姑) (r. 95–85 BC) requested a renewal of the heqin agreement, he demanded an annual tribute of {{convert|400000|l|USbu}} or 10,000 ''dan'' of wine, {{convert|100000|l|USbu}} or 5,000 ''hu'' of grain, and 10,000 bales of silk.<ref name="Yü 1986 397">{{Harvnb|Yü|1986|p=397}}.</ref><ref>''[[Book of Han]]'', [http://www.sidneyluo.net/a/a02/094a.htm vol. 94a].</ref> These amounts of wine, grain, and silk were considered to be a significant increase from earlier amounts of tribute, which must have been much less.<ref name="Yü 1986 397"/> Besides these arrangements, the most common commercial exchanges between the [[Xiongnu]] and Han merchants consisted of the trading of Xiongnu horses and [[Fur clothing|furs]] for Han agricultural foodstuffs and luxury items, most notably silk.<ref name="liu 1988 14"/> By means of the [[black market]], the Xiongnu were also able to smuggle Han [[History of ferrous metallurgy|iron weapons]] across the border.<ref name="liu 1988 14"/>
The Han established a diplomatic presence in the [[Tarim Basin]] of [[Central Asia]] during [[Emperor Wu of Han]]'s reign (141–87 BC). Han envoys brought gifts of sheep, gold, and silk to the urban oasis city-states.<ref name="liu 1988 14"/> The Chinese sometimes used gold as currency; however, silk was favored as a means to pay for food and lodging.<ref name="liu 1988 14"/> Once the Han had subjugated the Tarim Basin and [[Protectorate of the Western Regions|established a Protectorate there]], Han envoys in these states were given free food and lodging. These envoys were required to send tributary items of furs, precious stones, and delicacies such as Central Asian raisins to the Han court.<ref name="liu 1988 14"/> The [[Arsacid Empire|Arsacid]] court sent exotic animals including lions and ostriches to the Han court, and a king ruling in what is now [[Burma]] sent elephants and rhinoceroses.<ref name="de crespigny 2007 497 591">{{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|pp=497–591}}.</ref> Han diplomatic missions to royal courts across Asia were usually accompanied by trade caravans which earned substantial profits.<ref name="torday 114 117">{{Harvnb|Torday|1997|pp=114–117}}.</ref>
The Han court received tributary submission from the Xiongnu [[chanyu|leader]] Huhanye (呼韓邪) (r. 58–31 BC), an important rival to [[Zhizhi Chanyu]] (r. 56–36 BC, died at the [[Battle of Zhizhi]]). Huhanye's tribute, exchange of hostages, and presence at Chang'an in the [[Chinese New Year|New Year]] of 51 BC were rewarded with the following gifts from the emperor: {{convert|5|kg|ozt|abbr=on|lk=on}} of gold, 200,000 coins, 77 suits of clothes, 8,000 bales of silk fabric, {{convert|1500|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of silk floss, 15 horses, and {{convert|680000|l|USbu|abbr=on|lk=on}} of grain.<ref>{{Harvnb|Yü|1986|pp=395–396}}; {{Harvnb|Loewe|1986|pp=196–197}}.</ref> However, this is the only occurrence of rewarded gifts that present materials other than fabric. As shown in the table below, based upon Yü Ying-shih's "Han Foreign Relations" (1986), the gifts consisted only silk after 51 BC, and the Xiongnu leader's political submission was guaranteed only for as long as the Han could provide him with ever greater amounts of imperial largesse of silk with each succeeding visit to the Chinese court.<ref name="yü 1986 396 397"/>

The establishment of the [[Silk Road]] occurred during Wu's reign, owing to the efforts of the diplomat [[Zhang Qian]]. The increased demand for silk from the [[Roman Empire]] stimulated commercial traffic in both Central Asia and across the [[Indian Ocean]]. [[Roman commerce|Roman merchants]] sailed to [[Barbarikon]] near present-day [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]], and [[Bharuch|Barygaza]] in present-day [[Gujarat]], [[India]] to purchase Chinese silks (see [[Roman trade with India]]).<ref name="liu 1988 19">{{Harvnb|Liu|1988|p=19}}.</ref> When Emperor Wu conquered [[Nanyue]]—in what is now [[Southwest China]] and [[Northern and southern Vietnam|northern Vietnam]]—in 111 BC, overseas trade was extended to [[Southeast Asia]] and the Indian Ocean, as maritime merchants traded Han gold and silk for pearls, jade, lapis lazuli, and glasswares.<ref name="nishijima 1986 579 580">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=579–580}}.</ref>
The [[Book of Later Han]] states that Roman envoys sent by Emperor [[Marcus Aurelius]] (r. 161–180 AD), following a southern route, brought gifts to the court of [[Emperor Huan of Han]] (r. 146–168 AD) in 166 AD.<ref>{{Harvnb|Liu|1988|p=19}}; {{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|p=600}}; {{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|pp=579–580}}.</ref> This Roman mission followed an unsuccessful attempt by the Han diplomat [[Gan Ying]] to reach [[Rome]] in 97. Gan Ying was delayed at the [[Persian Gulf]], by [[Arsacid Empire|Arsacid]] authorities, and could only make a report on Rome based on oral accounts.<ref name="nishijima 1986 579">{{Harvnb|Nishijima|1986|p=579}}.</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|pp=239–240}}.</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Yü|1986|pp=460–461}}.</ref> Historians [[Charles Hucker]] and [[Rafe de Crespigny]] both speculate that the Roman mission of 166 AD involved enterprising Roman merchants instead of actual diplomats;<ref>{{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=191}}; {{Harvnb|de Crespigny|2007|p=600}}.</ref> Hucker writes:<ref name="hucker 1975 191"/>
<blockquote>Tributary missions from vassal states were commonly allowed to include traders, who thus gained opportunities to do business in the capital markets. No doubt a large proportion of what the Chinese court chose to call tributary missions were in fact shrewdly organized commercial ventures by foreign merchants with no diplomatic status at all. This was unquestionably the case, most notably, with a group of traders who appeared on the south coast in 166 AD claiming to be envoys from the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius Antoninus.<ref name="hucker 1975 191">{{Harvnb|Hucker|1975|p=191}}.</ref></blockquote> {{multiple image| align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = | footer_align = left | image1 = | width1 = 140 | caption1 = A [[Ancient Roman art|Roman]] [[gilded]] silver plate with a [[relief]] image of the Greco-Roman god [[Dionysus]], dated 2nd-3rd century AD and originally made in the [[Eastern Mediterranean]], found at an archaeological site in [[Jingyuan County, Gansu]], China<ref>{{Harvnb|Harper|2002|pp=106–107}}.</ref> | image2 = Green glass Roman cup unearthed at Eastern Han tomb, Guixian, China.jpg| width2 = 200 | caption2 =A green [[Roman glass]] cup unearthed from an [[Eastern Han Dynasty]] (25-220 AD) tomb, [[Guangxi]], China}}
The main trade route leading into Han China passed first through [[Kashgar]], yet [[Hellenistic civilization|Hellenized]] [[Bactria]] further west was the central node of international trade.<ref name="liu 1988 26">{{Harvnb|Liu|1988|p=26}}.</ref> By the 1st century AD, Bactria and much of Central Asia and [[North India]] were controlled by the [[Kushan Empire]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Liu|1988|pp=26–29}}.</ref> Silk was the main export item from China to [[India]]. [[Economic history of India|Indian merchants]] brought various goods to China, including tortoise shell, gold, silver, copper, iron, lead, tin, fine cloth, woolen textiles, perfume and incense, crystal sugar, pepper, ginger, salt, coral, pearls, glass items, and Roman wares.<ref>{{Harvnb|Liu|1988|pp=52–53, 64–65}}.</ref> Indian merchants brought Roman [[styrax]] and [[frankincense]] to China, while the Chinese knew [[bdellium]] as a fragrant item from Persia, although it was native to [[West India]].<ref name="liu 1988 63">{{Harvnb|Liu|1988|p=63}}.</ref> The tall [[Ferghana horse]]s imported from [[Fergana]] were highly prized in Han China.<ref name="liu 1988 53">{{Harvnb|Liu|1988|p=53}}.</ref> The newly introduced exotic Central Asian [[grape]]s (i.e. ''[[vitis vinifera]]'') were used to make [[Wine in China|grape wine]], although the Chinese had [[rice wine]] before this.<ref name="gernet 1962 134 135">{{Harvnb|Gernet|1962|pp=134–135}}.</ref> [[Glass]] luxury items from ancient [[Mesopotamia]] have been found in Chinese tombs and dated to the late [[Spring and Autumn Period]] (771–476 BC). [[Roman glass]]wares have been found in Chinese tombs dating to the early 1st century BC, with the earliest specimen found at the southern Chinese seaport of [[Guangzhou]].<ref name="an 2002 79 83">{{Harvnb|An|2002|pp=79, 82–83}}.</ref> [[Silver (household)|Silverwares]] from [[Roman Empire|Roman-]] and [[Arsacid Empire|Arsacid]] territories have also been found at Han tomb sites.<ref>{{Harvnb|Harper|2002|pp=96–107}}.</ref>
